ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned additional vocab, more about Deaf culture, ASL literature, rhyming, etc.
Expand ASL vocab/fluency
I learned lots of new ASL vocabulary, and gained valuable knowledge about the history of ASL, as well as information about the Deaf community and Deaf culture.
Continued learning ASL sign production and reception. Because this is a higher level ASL course, we also learned about Deaf culture and more complex ASL poetry/literature/performance.
I learned about ASL vocabulary and grammar, as well as forms of media used in ASL.
General fluency, ASL lit and vocab exposure, storytelling

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths -- incredibly fun, felt like a family
Weaknesses -- not very clear direction for assignments or the service project

Strengths - I was very excited to go to class each day! There were many opportunities for us to communicate with one another and play games. 
Weaknesses - I felt that at times the course was a lot of review and we were not learning much new vocab.

Strength - the professors are incredibly kind
Weakness - lack of communication of assignments/grades

I loved how engaging the course was, and Dr. Conlin always encouraged everyone in class to participate in our fun class activities. One thing that could be improved is the Canvas page, as it was sometimes difficult to find assignments/where to submit assignments.

Strength of the course is the inclusive learning environment and constant practice of ASL skills. The class is taught voice-off, without interpreters, so it requires a high level of engagement. Weakness is that the course is not super organized, which is helpful for just constant ASL input, but can be challenging when we are trying to make sure we understood what was expected for assignments.

The small class size is great for practicing vocabulary with classmates. ASL is also a fun language to learn because of how it used different parts of the body. I wish that we spent a little more time learning and practicing vocabulary and grammar, though, because I think it wouldve made it easier to grasp concepts such as storytelling and media, which we focused on a lot throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! ASL is beautiful and so interesting.
ASL is so wonderful! It's an incredibly powerful community and language that I would recommend to anyone.
Yes, this class was fun, interesting and I learned a lot.
Yes! It's very low stress but high fun and you keep your ASL skills sharp
Absolutely! This was an amazing course and Dr. Conlin makes learning super fun!

I would recommend this course, with the caveat that an interest and engagement with ASL and the Deaf community is needed -- you get what you put into this course. Overall, I appreciated the exposure to ASL I had in this course, and I learned a lot in my final project about specific accessibility issues Yale's DHH community faces, different ASL art/poetry, and tried my hand at ASL storytelling/poetry.
I would recommend the course. Not only do you learn about ASL, but you also learn about Deaf culture, which people generally know very little about.
Yes! I loved ASL 3. Definitely take it, so much fun! I'm gonna miss my ASL fam!
